Description: The Acute Care Pediatric Nurse Practitioner (ACPNP) and Primary Care Pediatric Nurse Practitioner (PNP) dual track is designed for nurses who hold a baccalaureate degree in nursing and who wish to continue their education to the doctoral level. The dual track focuses on the care of children from birth through young adulthood with an emphasis on complex, chronic, acute, and critical pediatric illness. The PNP track also focuses on health promotion and health maintenance of infants and children. With this dual preparation, graduates will be eligible to take both the Acute Care CPNP exam and the Primary Care CPNP exam offered by the Pediatric Nursing Certification Board. Upon completion of the DNP program graduates are prepared for leadership roles to improve health outcomes of individuals and populations and to transform practice.

ProgramName: Master of Music in Performance
EnglishScore: International applicants must submit one of the following to demonstrate English proficiency: TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language) score of 80 on the iBT, IELTS (International English Language Testing System) score of 6.5, PTE (Pearson Test of English) score of 60, Duolingo score of 110, or ELS (English Language Services) Certificate of Completion of Level 112.
Concentration: piano, organ, voice, collaborative piano, and orchestral instruments (violin, viola, cello, double bass, flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, horn, trumpet, trombone, tuba, percussion, and harp)
Description: The Master of Music in Performance is offered with concentrations in piano, organ, voice, collaborative piano, and orchestral instruments (violin, viola, cello, double bass, flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, horn, trumpet, trombone, tuba, percussion, and harp). The degree normally requires four semesters of study, during which time the student must be enrolled for a minimum of 12 semester hours of credit during each of the first three semesters and for a minimum of one hour of credit for the final semester. The program of study includes private instruction in the major performance area, classes in music history and music theory, pedagogy courses, music electives, and large ensembles. The degree culminates in the presentation of a solo recital.
Accredidation: The Baylor University School of Music is a member of the National Association of Schools of Music and the Texas Association of Music Schools.

ProgramName: PhD in Philosophy
EnglishScore: Applicants who are not U.S. citizens are required to submit an official score report from one of the following English proficiency tests: TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo.
Description: Baylor's Ph.D. program in philosophy is a small, select program that prepares students for careers as professional philosophers. The Ph.D. program provides students with rigorous training for research and teaching in philosophy, with special emphasis on philosophy in the Christian tradition. The program is designed to be completed in five years. Students take twelve seminars over their first three years, three in each of the four main areas of the discipline: (1) History of Philosophy, (2) Metaphysics and Epistemology, (3) Value Theory, and (4) Special Topics (Logic, Philosophy of Religion, etc.). After their coursework is completed, students must pass two comprehensive exams and write a dissertation. Generous funding packages are available for all admitted students, including full-tuition remission and an annual stipend (currently $23,000). For more information, please visit the Graduate School page or contact the Director of Graduate Studies.
AverageScholarshipAmount: Full tuition scholarship plus a $26,000 stipend
ScholarshipAmount: Full tuition scholarship plus a $26,000 stipend

ProgramName: Doctor of Physical Therapy
EnglishScore: Applicants for whom English is not their first language are required to submit a satisfactory score on a test of English proficiency. Baylor's Graduate School accepts scores from the TOEFL (minimum 80 on iBT), IELTS (minimum 6.5), or Duolingo (minimum 110).
Requirements:
Bachelor's Degree: Applicants must have earned a bachelor's degree from a nationally-accredited U.S. institution or a foreign equivalent before the first day of class.
Prerequisite Courses: Applicants must complete the prerequisite courses with a C or better before the first day of class.
Grade Point Average (GPA): We require a minimum GPA of 3.0 in the prerequisite courses and the last 60 hours of coursework.
Graduate Record Examination (GRE): The GRE is not required for admission to the Baylor DPT program.
Observation Hours: A minimum of 100 observation hours are required under the supervision of a licensed physical therapist.
Letters of Recommendation: Two letters of recommendation are required. One must be from a licensed physical therapist and one must be from a college professor.
Essays: The PTCAS application requires one essay and the Baylor DPT supplemental application requires one essay.
Interview: After a holistic review of applications, qualified applicants will be invited to participate in a virtual interview with Baylor DPT faculty.
Technical Standards: Students admitted to the Baylor DPT program must be able to perform the essential functions of a physical therapy student, with or without reasonable accommodations.
Background Check: All accepted students must consent to and pass a background check prior to matriculation into the Baylor DPT program.
Department: Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences
Description: The Baylor University Doctor of Physical Therapy program is a two-year, hybrid-accelerated DPT program. Our program blends the best of online and hands-on learning. The Baylor DPT program spans 24 months (6 semesters) and includes 31 weeks of full-time clinical education experience. We prepare our graduates to be leaders and innovators in the profession, well-prepared for autonomous practice. Our innovative curriculum is designed to facilitate student learning and clinical reasoning through a case-based and evidence-based approach to teaching. Students engage in courses online and then travel to campus for intensive, hands-on lab immersion sessions. The DPT program is housed in the Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences.
Accredidation: The Doctor of Physical Therapy Program at Baylor University is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation in Physical Therapy Education (CAPTE), 3030 Potomac Ave., Suite 100, Alexandria, Virginia 22305-3085; telephone: 703-706-3245; email: accreditation@apta.org; website: http://www.capteonline.org. If needing to contact the program/institution directly, please call 254-710-3111 or email DPTadmissions@baylor.edu.
ScholarshipAmount: All admitted students receive a scholarship equivalent to 30% of tuition, with opportunities for merit scholarships up to 50% of tuition.

ProgramName: Doctor of Physical Therapy (Army-Baylor)
Requirements: A Bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. GRE within the last 5 years. Minimum GRE scores: Verbal 150, Quantitative 150. U.S. Citizenship. A successful interview. Medical examination and must meet U.S. Army standards. Competitive candidates usually have GPAs above a 3.5. A minimum of 100 observation hours is required with a licensed physical therapist. Observation hours must be documented and signed by the supervising PT. All prerequisite coursework must be completed with a grade of "C" or better prior to the start of the program in July.
Department: Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences
Description: The U.S. Army-Baylor University Doctoral Program in Physical Therapy is a top-ranked program that has been producing leaders in the field of physical therapy for over 50 years. Our graduates are problem-solvers who are dedicated to serving their country and their communities as members of the Armed Forces. They are prepared to provide evidence-based care in a variety of settings, from combat zones to hospitals and clinics. The Army-Baylor DPT program is a unique blend of academic rigor, clinical experience, and military training. Our students are challenged to think critically and creatively, and to develop the skills and knowledge they need to be successful in their careers. They are also taught the importance of teamwork, leadership, and service. We believe that our graduates are the future of physical therapy, and we are proud to play a role in shaping their development. If you are looking for a challenging and rewarding career, we encourage you to consider the U.S. Army-Baylor University Doctoral Program in Physical Therapy.
Accredidation: The U.S. Army-Baylor University Doctor of Physical Therapy Program at Baylor University is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation in Physical Therapy Education (CAPTE), 3030 Potomac Ave., Suite 100, Alexandria, Virginia 22305-3085; telephone: 703-706-3245; email: accreditation@apta.org; website: http://www.capteonline.org. If needing to contact the program/institution directly, please call 210-221-6456 or email usarmy.jbsa.medical-coe.mbx.dpt-program@health.mil.

ProgramName: Physician Assistant Studies (Army-Baylor)
Requirements:
The U.S. Army-Baylor University DScPA program is unique among PA doctoral programs in that we accept applicants directly into one of two tracks: Emergency Medicine or Surgery. The ideal applicant is an experienced Army PA who can successfully complete a fast-paced, rigorous 18-month academic and clinical curriculum. At a minimum, applicants must meet the following prerequisites to be considered for admission to the program:

* Be an active duty, commissioned officer in the U.S. Army
* Be a graduate of the Interservice Physician Assistant Program (IPAP)
* Hold a master’s degree from a regionally-accredited university
* Have at least 4 years of experience as a U.S. Army PA
* Meet the requirements for and submit an application to the Army Medical Department’s Long Term Health and Education (LTHET) program
* Submit a completed application to the Baylor University Graduate School
Department: Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences
Description: The U.S. Army-Baylor University Master of Physician Assistant Studies (MPAS) degree program is a 29-month graduate program that consists of a 16-month didactic phase and a 13-month clinical phase. The didactic curriculum is an organ-system based, spiraling curriculum that emphasizes active and collaborative learning. Courses in the basic sciences, clinical medicine, and professional development are integrated in a manner that requires students to apply knowledge of the basic sciences to clinical situations. Throughout the didactic phase, small group learning, case-based learning, simulation, and hands-on laboratory experiences in anatomy, clinical skills, and emergency medicine procedures prepare students for entry into the clinical phase of the program. During the 13-month clinical phase, students complete 10 core clinical rotations and 3 elective rotations at one of several Army, Navy, or Air Force Medical Treatment Facilities. The program curriculum is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary for the development of a competent, compassionate Physician Assistant who is prepared for clinical practice in any setting and in any specialty.
Accredidation: The Accreditation Review Commission on Education for the Physician Assistant, Inc. (ARC-PA) has granted Accreditation-Continued status to the Interservice Physician Assistant Program sponsored by the Army Medical Center of Excellence. Accreditation-Continued is an accreditation status granted when a currently accredited program is in compliance with the ARC-PA Standards. Accreditation remains in effect until the program closes or withdraws from the accreditation process or until accreditation is withdrawn for failure to comply with the Standards. The approximate date for the next validation review of the program by the ARC-PA will be March 2029. The review date is contingent upon continued compliance with the Accreditation Standards and ARC-PA policy.

ProgramName: Master of Physician Assistant Studies
EnglishScore: All international applicants must submit a test score that shows an adequate level of English proficiency. The Graduate School accepts the following tests: TOEFL, IELTS, Duolingo. Minimum scores are 80 on the TOEFL iBT, 6.5 on the IELTS, or 110 on Duolingo. The English proficiency test requirement may be waived if the applicant has a bachelor's degree from an accredited U.S. institution.
Department: Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences
Description: The Baylor University Physician Assistant Program will prepare graduates to serve as physician assistants. Housed in the Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences, the program is a full-time, 28-month curriculum leading to the Master of Physician Assistant Studies degree. The program is designed to provide a broad-based medical education that will enable graduates to provide patient care in a wide range of medical settings and specialties. The program emphasizes the acquisition of knowledge and the development of clinical skills and acumen necessary to function as a competent health care provider.
Accredidation:
The ARC-PA has granted Accreditation-Provisional status to the Baylor University Physician Assistant Program sponsored by Baylor University.

Accreditation-Provisional is an accreditation status granted when the plans and resource allocation, if fully implemented as planned, of a proposed program that has not yet enrolled students appear to demonstrate the program’s ability to meet the ARC-PA Standards or when a program holding Accreditation-Provisional status appears to demonstrate continued progress in complying with the Standards as it prepares for the graduation of the first class (cohort) of students.

Accreditation-Provisional does not ensure any subsequent accreditation status. It is limited to no more than five years from matriculation of the first class.

The program’s accreditation history can be viewed on the ARC-PA website at http://www.arc-pa.org/accreditation-history-baylor-university/.

ProgramName: PhD in Physics & Astronomy
EnglishScore: For applicants whose native language is not English, one of the following is required to demonstrate English proficiency: TOEFL (minimum score of 80 on the iBT), IELTS (minimum score of 6.5), PTE (minimum score of 60), Duolingo (minimum score of 110), or ELS (minimum score of 112).
Description: Welcome to Graduate Studies in Physics at Baylor! The Baylor University Department of Physics offers M.S. and Ph.D. degrees. The department is a vibrant, exciting, and friendly place to pursue graduate work. It is also an integral component of the research mission of Baylor University. The graduate physics program at Baylor is designed to provide students with a strong background in both experimental and theoretical physics through formal course work and research. After completing a core curriculum that provides a solid foundation in the fundamental areas of physics, students specialize in a particular subfield and become deeply involved in state-of-the-art research.
ScholarshipAmount: Full tuition waiver plus a stipend of up to $32,000 per year
ScholarshipPercentage: 100% of admitted PhD students receive a full tuition waiver.
ScholarshipType: Teaching Assistantships, Research Assistantships, Fellowships, Tuition Waivers

ProgramName: Master of Science in Physics
EnglishScore: All international applicants must submit an English proficiency score. Baylor University accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, and DuoLingo exams. The Graduate School recommends a minimum score of 80 on the iBT (TOEFL), a minimum overall score of 6.5 (IELTS), and a minimum overall score of 110 (DuoLingo).
Description: The Department of Physics offers graduate work leading to the Master of Arts, Master of Science, and Doctor of Philosophy degrees. Graduate study and research opportunities are available in atomic and molecular physics, astrophysics and space physics, condensed matter and materials physics, gravitation and cosmology, nuclear and particle physics, and physics education. Opportunities for interdisciplinary research also exist.

ProgramName: Master of Music in Piano Pedagogy and Performance
EnglishScore: Applicants who are not U.S. citizens are required to submit an official score report from one of the following exams: the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), or the Duolingo English Test. The Graduate School requires a minimum score of 80 on the internet-based TOEFL (iBT), a minimum overall score of 6.5 on the IELTS, or a minimum score of 110 on the Duolingo English Test.
Requirements: To be considered for admission, applicants must complete the online GoBaylor application for the Graduate School and submit the School of Music application. Required materials for all graduate applicants include a Curriculum Vitae or Résumé, a statement of purpose of approximately 300 words, a scholarly writing sample (preferably on a musical topic), three letters of recommendation, and transcripts from all institutions from which a degree was received. For the Master of Music in Piano Pedagogy and Performance, applicants must also schedule and complete an audition. The audition should last at least 20 minutes and consist of memorized works from at least three of the four major style periods: Baroque, Classic, Romantic, and 20th/21st Century. One work on the program must be from the Baroque or Classic period. A complete list of repertoire studied should be uploaded prior to the audition.
Description: The Master of Music degree in piano pedagogy and performance is an innovative program that offers a unique course of study for the aspiring piano teacher. The degree track provides a balance between pedagogical training, performance studies, and music scholarship. It is designed to prepare graduates to be effective and successful studio teachers as well as be qualified to pursue a doctoral degree. Students in the program develop their skills as artists and teachers through applied lessons and recitals, pedagogy courses, and a supervised teaching internship in the Baylor Piano Laboratory Program. They also gain additional teaching experience in group and individual settings with children and university-level students. Assistantships are available in both piano and piano pedagogy. Many of our recent graduates have gone on to doctoral programs at prestigious music schools and have also established successful independent piano studios.
Accredidation: Baylor University is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music. The undergraduate and graduate curricula for the School of Music have been approved by NASM.

ProgramName: PhD in Political Science
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit a score from one of the following tests: TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo. An applicant is exempt from the English proficiency test requirement if they have received a bachelor's degree or higher from a U.S. institution or from an institution in a country where English is the official language.
Requirements:
A completed online application and application fee are required to apply.

Additional application requirements include:
- A Bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited U.S. institution or a recognized international equivalent
- Official transcripts from all universities attended
- A statement of purpose of approximately 500 words
- Three letters of recommendation
- A résumé or curriculum vitae (CV)
- A writing sample
- GRE General Test (Baylor's GRE code is 6032)
- Official TOEFL or IELTS scores (for international students)

ProgramName: PhD in Preaching
EnglishScore: Most international applicants are required to take an English proficiency exam. The Graduate School accepts the TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo exams. Minimum score requirements are TOEFL iBT: 80, IELTS: 6.5, Duolingo: 110. An applicant is exempt from the English proficiency exam requirement if they are a citizen of certain countries or if they hold a bachelor's degree or higher from a U.S. accredited institution.
Description: The Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) in Preaching is an advanced academic degree designed for the development of teacher-scholars in the field of homiletics. It seeks to form students for vocations of research, scholarship, and teaching in universities, theological seminaries, and divinity schools and for the equipping of church leaders. At the same time, because preaching is an ecclesial and theological practice as well as an academic discipline, the program aims to promote research that enriches the practice of preaching in the church. The Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) in Preaching is offered by Baylor University's Graduate School and is delivered by the faculty of George W. Truett Theological Seminary. Upon successful completion of the program, the degree is conferred by Baylor University.
ScholarshipAmount: Full-tuition scholarship and a generous stipend

ProgramName: Doctor of Nursing Practice in Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner
EnglishScore: Applicants who are not U.S. citizens are required to submit proof of English proficiency. The Graduate School accepts the following as proof of English proficiency: A bachelor's degree from an accredited U.S. institution or from an institution in a country where English is the official language. TOEFL: score of 80 on the iBT, IELTS: score of 6.5, Duolingo: score of 110.
Requirements: A completed application and all required materials must be submitted for an application to be reviewed. Requirements include: a completed GoGarland Application with a $50 non-refundable fee; official transcripts from all degree-granting institutions (minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA required); three professional or academic letters of recommendation; a curriculum vita or resume; a typed, 300-500 word Statement of Purpose addressing specific prompts; and a current unencumbered license to practice as a Registered Nurse in the United States. An interview is required for admission. The GRE is waived for DNP applicants with a 3.2 or higher cumulative GPA or a 3.4 GPA in their Master’s degree; for those not qualifying for the waiver, GRE scores from the last five years are required. International applicants must submit TOEFL (minimum 80 iBT) or IELTS (minimum 6.5) scores.
Description: The Baylor University Louise Herrington School of Nursing Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) program is a practice-focused doctoral program. This program is designed for nurses who have a bachelor's or master's degree and want to become a Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner (PMHNP). The post-master's DNP program is offered online. It can be completed in approximately two years on a full-time basis and three years on a part-time basis. The BSN to DNP option is also available in an online format. Full-time students typically complete this option in four years and part-time students can do so in five years.
Accredidation: The Doctor of Nursing Practice degree program at Baylor University is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).

ProgramName: PhD in Psychology and Neuroscience
EnglishScore: All international applicants must submit an English proficiency test score. Baylor accepts scores from TOEFL, IELTS, and Duolingo. The recommended minimum scores are 80 on the internet-based TOEFL, 6.5 on the IELTS, or 110 on Duolingo. The test of English proficiency can be waived if the applicant has a bachelor’s degree or higher from an accredited U.S. institution.
Description: The Department of Psychology and Neuroscience at Baylor University offers a Ph.D. in Psychology with four areas of specialization: Behavioral Neuroscience, Social Psychology, General Experimental Psychology, and Clinical Psychology (Psy.D.). We offer a research-intensive program designed to prepare students for careers in research and teaching in a variety of settings (e.g., academic, industrial, governmental). Although a student’s interests typically fall within one of the primary areas of research, all graduate students develop a strong general background in psychology that is reflected in the Ph.D. in Psychology. We strive for a student-faculty ratio (typically 2:1) that is optimal for providing individualized instruction in small classes, seminars, and research laboratories. As a result, admission to our program is highly competitive. During the most recent admissions cycle we admitted 12 new Ph.D. students and 12 new Psy.D. students. All doctoral students who are in good academic standing are supported by a full tuition waiver and a competitive stipend for five years. More than half of our doctoral students are also supported by a prestigious University Graduate Fellowship. Students pursuing the Ph.D. may specialize in Behavioral Neuroscience, Social Psychology, or General Experimental Psychology.

ProgramName: Master of Public Health
EnglishScore: All international applicants must submit an English proficiency test score. Baylor accepts TOEFL (minimum 80 iBT), IELTS (minimum 6.5), Duolingo (minimum 110), or PTE (minimum 60). An applicant is exempt from the test requirement if they have received a bachelor’s degree from an accredited U.S. institution.
Requirements: Completed online application and application fee. Transcripts. Statement of Purpose: This should be one to two pages in length and detail your reasons for pursuing the MPH degree, your professional goals, and your specific areas of interest within public health. Resume/Curriculum Vitae: This should detail your work experience, service, leadership, and honors/awards. Three letters of recommendation: These should be from individuals who can speak to your academic ability and/or work ethic and experience. Recommendations are submitted electronically through the application. GRE: GRE test scores are optional for applicants with a cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher. For applicants with a GPA below 3.0, the GRE is required.
Department: Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences
Concentration: Community Health Science, Environmental Health Science, Epidemiology, Global Health, Physical Activity & Nutrition
Description: The Baylor University Master of Public Health (MPH) degree program in the Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences provides a Christ-centered environment to prepare culturally competent, ethical public health professionals for careers in a variety of sectors. With a focus on strategies to prevent disease and promote health and well-being in diverse populations, our curriculum is practice-based and provides students with opportunities to apply what they learn in the classroom to real-world settings. Baylor’s MPH program is small by design, which creates a low student-to-faculty ratio and ensures a highly relational and personalized learning experience. Students receive individualized attention from nationally- and internationally-recognized faculty who are committed to student success. Opportunities abound for students to engage in ongoing faculty research and to participate in public health initiatives both locally and globally. The MPH program has a strong sense of community and provides a supportive learning environment for all students.
Accredidation: The Baylor University Public Health Program is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH). Our initial accreditation was awarded for a five-year term, extending to July 1, 2023. The Program submitted a self-study in 2022 and had a site visit in fall 2022. The Program has been recommended for re-accreditation for a seven-year term, extending to July 1, 2030.

ProgramName: Master of Public Policy and Administration
EnglishScore: All international applicants must submit one of the following scores to fulfill the English proficiency requirement: TOEFL (minimum score of 80 iBT), IELTS (minimum overall score of 6.5), PTE (minimum score of 60), or Duolingo English Test (DET) (a minimum score of 110). Applicants may be exempt if they are a citizen of certain countries or have completed a bachelor's or master's degree from a regionally accredited U.S. institution.
Requirements: A bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited U.S. institution or a recognized international university. A minimum of 3.0 GPA on a 4.0 scale. The GRE is optional. Strong applicants who do not submit a GRE score will still be considered for admission. Official transcripts from all institutions from which a degree was received. A completed application and application fee. A personal statement of 500 words or less describing why you are a good fit for Baylor’s MPPA program, including how your education, experience, and career goals have led you to apply. Three letters of recommendation. At least two of the three letters should be from professors who have taught you in college courses. In cases where the applicant has been out of school for more than five years, letters from employers and other non-relatives who know the applicant well are acceptable. Resume. Writing sample of 1,000 words or less. This should be an analytical paper you have written for an undergraduate course, preferably in a social science or humanities class.
Concentration: Security Studies, Public Health, World Affairs, Local Government, Non-Profit Management
Description: Baylor's Master of Public Policy and Administration (MPPA) program, offered through the Department of Political Science in the College of Arts and Sciences, equips students to serve in the public or non-profit sectors. Our curriculum provides students with a strong foundation of knowledge about the public policy process as well as the analytical skills necessary to be an effective public manager. Students in our program frequently get to work on real-world policy and administrative problems for public and non-profit organizations. Students gain practical experience through an internship in the public or nonprofit sectors.

ProgramName: Master of Science in School Psychology
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit a score from an English proficiency test. The Graduate School requires a minimum TOEFL score of 80 on the iBT, a 6.5 on the IELTS, or a 110 on Duolingo. Applicants are exempt from the English proficiency test requirement if they hold a bachelor's or master's degree from an accredited institution in the United States.
Requirements:
The admissions process for the M.S.Ed. in School Psychology is managed through Baylor’s Graduate School. Prospective students must submit all application materials through the Graduate School's application portal. Required materials include:
* Completed online application and application fee
* Bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited U.S. institution or a recognized international university
* Official transcripts from all institutions from which a degree was received
* Statement of Purpose
* Resume or Curriculum Vitae
* Three letters of recommendation
* Official GRE scores (verbal and quantitative)*
* *GRE is optional for the 2024 admissions cycle.
Description: The Master of Science (MS) program in School Psychology is designed for students who want to become a Licensed Specialist in School Psychology (LSSP). Students must complete the Master of Science (MS) and the Education Specialist (EdS) degrees in order to be eligible for LSSP licensure.
ScholarshipAmount: SOE Scholarships range from $1,000 to $5,000. Graduate Assistantship stipends are a minimum of $8,000 annually. Practicum placements offer an annual stipend of approximately $10,000.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based Scholarships, Graduate Assistantships, Practicum Stipends

ProgramName: Master of Science in Sport Pedagogy
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit a TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo score. Minimum scores required are: TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language) score of 80 on the iBT, IELTS (International English Language Testing System) score of 6.5, or Duolingo score of 110. The test requirement may be waived if the applicant has completed a bachelor's degree or a master's degree at a U.S. institution.
Requirements: Complete the online application and pay the nonrefundable application fee. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. An official transcript is one that is sent directly from the institution to Baylor. A bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited US institution or a recognized international institution. A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required. In some instances, students with slightly lower GPAs may be considered for admission based on the strength of other credentials. GRE scores are not required for this program. Three letters of recommendation from individuals who can speak to your academic potential, character and fitness for graduate study. At least two of the letters should be from former professors. Statement of Purpose: The statement of purpose should be a concise, well-written essay about your background and reasons for pursuing a graduate degree in this particular program at Baylor University. This statement is an important part of your application, and allows the admissions committee to evaluate your writing ability and to determine if your goals are a good match for our program. Résumé/Vita
Department: Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences
Description: The Master of Science degree in Sport Pedagology is a 36-hour program designed to enhance the knowledge base of teachers and coaches in the various aspects of physical education and athletic coaching. Baylor's Sport Pedagogy program is committed to developing leaders in the field and promoting a physically active lifestyle for all individuals. The degree plan has both a thesis and non-thesis option and is individualized to meet the specific career goals of each student. The degree can typically be completed in one and a half to two years. The purpose of this degree is to prepare individuals for careers in teaching and coaching at the elementary, secondary, and junior college level. The program may also provide the foundation for students who plan to continue their education at the doctoral level.
ScholarshipType: Graduate School scholarships, Departmental scholarships, Assistantships (Graduate, Teaching, Research)

ProgramName: Master of Arts (Curriculum and Instruction)/Master of Divinity Joint Degree
EnglishScore: All international applicants must submit an English proficiency exam score. The scores must be no more than two years old. We accept the TOEFL (minimum score of 80 on the iBT), the IELTS (minimum overall score of 6.5), the Duolingo English Test (minimum score of 110), or the Pearson Test of English (PTE) (minimum score of 60).
Requirements: Students pursuing the joint degree program must be admitted to both the MA program in the School of Education and to the MDiv program in George W. Truett Theological Seminary. Therefore, students must complete the applications for both programs to be considered.
Department: George W. Truett Theological Seminary and School of Education
Description: The School of Education and George W. Truett Theological Seminary offer a joint degree program leading to the Master of Arts (M.A.) in Curriculum and Instruction and the Master of Divinity (M.Div.). Students complete the requirements for both degrees in a shortened time frame. The purpose of the joint degree program is to prepare persons for a variety of leadership roles in church and educational settings. Persons holding both degrees might serve in such roles as ministers of education in churches, leaders of denominational agencies, curriculum writers, or college teachers in church-related colleges. The total number of hours required for the joint degree is 99, 63 in the seminary and 36 in the School of Education. The 36 hours in Curriculum and Instruction constitute the Master of Arts degree.
ScholarshipType: Truett Scholarships, Baylor Ministry Scholarships, Denominational Scholarships, External Scholarships

ProgramName: Master of Business Administration/Juris Doctor Joint Degree
EnglishScore: Baylor University requires a minimum score on one of these English language proficiency tests: TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo.
Requirements: Students must apply separately and be admitted to both the Law School and the Business School. Interested students must submit an application to the Graduate Business School by the appropriate deadline.
Department: Baylor Law School and Hankamer School of Business
Description: The joint JD/MBA degree program allows a student to obtain both a Juris Doctor from Baylor Law and a Master of Business Administration from Baylor’s Hankamer School of Business. By pursuing the joint degree, the total time and course work for the two degrees can be significantly reduced. For students interested in careers that merge law and business, the JD/MBA joint degree provides valuable training in both disciplines and an excellent foundation for careers in business law or executive leadership.

ProgramName: Master of Business Administration/Master of Divinity Joint Degree
EnglishScore: The TOEFL, IELTS, or PTE is required of all international applicants except those from countries where English is the official language. The Duolingo test is not accepted for MBA programs.
Requirements: The joint M.B.A./M.Div. is comprised of two separate degree programs housed in separate academic units. Therefore, applicants for this joint degree must apply and be accepted to both programs. Acceptance into one program does not guarantee acceptance into the other. Applications are reviewed separately. Please visit the websites below to apply for each program.
Department: Hankamer School of Business / George W. Truett Theological Seminary
Fees: Hankamer School of Business (MBA): $26,051 per semester; George W. Truett Theological Seminary (MDiv): $912 per credit hour
Description: The MBA/MDiv is a joint degree program of the Hankamer School of Business and the George W. Truett Theological Seminary. Students in the joint program earn two separate degrees: a Master of Business Administration and a Master of Divinity. This program provides an opportunity for students to gain the skills needed to engage in various forms of ministry that require business acumen, including non-profit management and minister of administration/executive pastor roles in larger churches. Similarly, students looking to enter the corporate world can gain a theologically-informed ethical and social perspective through Truett Seminary's MDiv curriculum.
Accredidation: Baylor's MBA program is accredited by the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB), and Truett Seminary is accredited by the Association of Theological Schools (ATS).

ProgramName: Master of Business Administration/Master of Engineering Joint Degree
EnglishScore: Proficiency in English is a requirement for admission to Baylor University for all applicants. Applicants who are not U.S. citizens and do not hold lawful permanent resident status must submit one of the following to demonstrate English proficiency: TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language), IELTS (International English Language Testing System), PTE (Pearson Test of English), Duolingo English Test.
Department: Hankamer School of Business and School of Engineering and Computer Science
Fees: $25,823 per semester for MBA courses (flat rate for 9+ hours); $2,246 per credit hour for Engineering courses
Description: The Hankamer School of Business and the School of Engineering and Computer Science offer a joint degree program leading to the Master of Business Administration (MBA) and the Master of Engineering (ME) degrees. This joint degree program provides a unique opportunity for individuals with undergraduate degrees in engineering, computer science, or other related technical fields to develop both their technical skills and business acumen to prepare them for leadership positions in technology-based organizations.
CostPerCredit: $2,869 for MBA; $2,246 for Engineering & Computer Science
ScholarshipPercentage: 25% to 100% of tuition for MBA program

ProgramName: Master of Business Administration/Master of Science in Business Analytics Joint Degree
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit a score from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), or the Duolingo English Test.
Requirements: The application process for the dual MBA/MSBA degree follows the same requirements as the Full-Time MBA. Applicants must submit one application and select the dual degree option. Required application components include: an online application and fee, two required essays (and one optional), a professional résumé, unofficial transcripts from all universities attended, two professional letters of recommendation, and a video essay. GMAT, GRE, or Executive Assessment scores are also required, though a test waiver may be available for eligible candidates. Interviews are by invitation only.
Description: The MBA/MSBA Joint Degree is a graduate-level program that merges the comprehensive business education of the Master of Business Administration (MBA) with the specialized data analytics expertise of the Master of Science in Business Analytics (MSBA). This integrated curriculum is designed to equip students with a unique and powerful combination of skills, preparing them for leadership roles in a data-driven world. This joint degree is an efficient and cost-effective way to get two advanced degrees in a shorter period of time. You'll gain a strong foundation in business disciplines through the Baylor MBA and MSBA curricula.
Accredidation: The Hankamer School of Business is accredited by AACSB International—the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.

ProgramName: Master of Business Administration/Master of Science in Information Systems Joint Degree
EnglishScore:
All international applicants must demonstrate proficiency in English. You can do this in one of three ways:
1. Provide an official score report for the TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo.
2. Show that you have a bachelor's degree (or higher) from a U.S. university or a university in an English-speaking country.
3. Provide an official score report showing successful completion of Level 112 at an ELS Language Center.
Requirements: Online Application and Application Fee; Transcripts: from all institutions from which a degree was received; Test Scores: GMAT or GRE (waiver may be available); Essay Questions: Two required; Resume; Letters of Recommendation: Two required; Video Essay: One required; Interview: By invitation only; TOEFL or IELTS: For international applicants.
Description: The MBA/MSIS joint degree is a 64-credit hour program that prepares students for the challenges of managing in an increasingly technological business environment. Students take MBA core classes that provide a solid business foundation and MSIS core classes that develop specialized technical expertise. This combination of business and IT skills makes our graduates highly marketable.
Accredidation: AACSB International

ProgramName: Master of Business Administration/Master of Social Work Joint Degree
EnglishScore: International applicants are required to submit an official English language proficiency score report. Accepted tests include TOEFL (iBT), IELTS, PTE, and Duolingo.
Department: Hankamer School of Business and Diana R. Garland School of Social Work
Description: The Hankamer School of Business and the Diana R. Garland School of Social Work jointly offer a program in which a student can obtain both an MBA and an MSW degree. The joint degree program prepares students to become managers and leaders in various businesses and social service agencies that may be for profit, nonprofit, or governmental.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, Dean's Scholarships, Matching Scholarships, Ministerial Scholarship

ProgramName: Master of Music (Church Music)/Master of Divinity Joint Degree
EnglishScore: All international applicants whose native language is not English must submit a score from an English proficiency test such as TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo. The Graduate School prefers a TOEFL score of 80 (iBT), an IELTS score of 6.5, or a Duolingo score of 110.
Requirements:
All applicants must submit the online application through the Graduate School and pay the appropriate application fee.
Official transcripts from every institution of higher learning from which the applicant received 30 or more hours of academic credit.
Resume or curriculum vitae
3 letters of recommendation
Personal statement (statement of purpose)
A live or recorded audition.
A scholarly writing sample (research paper) of at least ten pages on a music topic with a bibliography.
Applicants whose native language is not English must submit a satisfactory score on the TOEFL or IELTS exam.
Applicants must be accepted independently to the School of Music and to George W. Truett Theological Seminary.
The GRE is not required for admission to the M.M. program.
Department: School of Music and George W. Truett Theological Seminary
Description: The joint Master of Music in Church Music and Master of Divinity degree is a cooperative program of the School of Music and George W. Truett Theological Seminary. This degree program allows the student to combine the Master of Music degree in Church Music with the Master of Divinity degree. The purpose of the joint degree is to equip students for ministry in which music and the pastoral arts are combined. Graduates of this program will be equipped for a variety of leadership positions in Christian churches and other ministry contexts.
Accredidation: The School of Music is an accredited member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM). The George W. Truett Theological Seminary is accredited by the Association of Theological Schools in the United States and Canada (ATS).
CostPerCredit: $805 per credit hour for the first 36 hours, and $2,277 per credit hour for the remainder.

ProgramName: Master of Public Policy and Administration/Juris Doctor Joint Degree
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit a score from one of the following tests: TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo.
Requirements: Students must meet the entrance requirements for both the law school and the Graduate School. Students should apply to both programs simultaneously. Acceptance into one program does not guarantee acceptance into the other. If accepted to both programs, students will enroll in the law school for their first year of study. For information about the Law School application, go to the Law School website. The Graduate School requires the following for the MPPA application: Completed online application, Application fee, Official transcripts, Three letters of recommendation, A statement of purpose of approximately 300 words, A résumé or C.V., A writing sample is optional but not required. The GRE is optional. Students who submit a GRE will be considered for a higher graduate assistantship stipend.
Department: College of Arts & Sciences and Baylor Law School
Description: Baylor University offers a Juris Doctor (JD) and Master of Public Policy and Administration (MPPA) joint degree program that allows a student to complete both degrees in a shorter amount of time than would be required to complete them separately. The joint degree program gives students the opportunity to gain a deeper understanding of the political system at the local, state, national and international levels and to prepare for a career in public service. Students take courses in the School of Law and the Graduate School at Baylor University and receive two separate degrees.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based (fellowships, research assistantships, and teaching assistantships)

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education (Curriculum and Instruction)/Master of Divinity Joint Degree
Department: School of Education and George W. Truett Theological Seminary
Description: This joint degree provides students with an integrated program of study leading to the Master of Divinity and the Master of Science in Education degrees. It is for those who are preparing for ministry and educational leadership in the church as well as in Christian schools. Students receive professional training from both the School of Education and George W. Truett Theological Seminary. This joint degree is designed for those who have been called to specialized ministry and sense the need for comprehensive training in both theological studies and education. It requires completion of coursework in both areas, with a minimum of 24 semester hours in the School of Education (EDP, TED, or EDL courses), in addition to required coursework for the MDiv.
CostPerCredit: School of Education: $2,056/credit hour; George W. Truett Theological Seminary: $1,003/credit hour

ProgramName: Master of Taxation/Juris Doctor Joint Degree
EnglishScore: All international applicants must submit an English proficiency test score. We accept the TOEFL, IELTS, and Duolingo English tests.
Department: Hankamer School of Business and Baylor Law School
Description: The joint Master of Taxation/Juris Doctor degree is a three-year program sponsored by the Law School and the Hankamer School of Business. It is designed to produce a lawyer who also has an in-depth knowledge of taxation. In the current job market, this combination provides a distinct competitive advantage for a law school graduate. Typically, a graduate will seek employment as an associate in a law firm or with a "Big Four" or smaller accounting firm. As an MTAX/JD student, you will enroll in the School of Law and concurrently pursue the MTAX degree. To complete the MTAX portion of the joint degree, you must be admitted into the MTAX program, complete all undergraduate prerequisite courses required for the MTAX degree, and take five graduate tax courses at the Hankamer School of Business.

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Teaching
LiveDate: The application for Spring 2026, Summer 2026, and Fall 2026 will open in mid-August 2025.
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit a score from one of the following tests: TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language), IELTS (International English Language Testing System), or the Duolingo English Test. The minimum required score on the TOEFL is 80 on the internet-based test (iBT) or 550 on the paper-based test (PBT). The minimum required score on the IELTS is 6.5. The minimum required score on the Duolingo English Test is 110. An applicant is exempt from the English proficiency test requirement if they have a bachelor's degree (or higher) from a U.S. regionally accredited university.
Concentration: Elementary Education (Grades EC-6), Middle Grades (Grades 4-8), Secondary Education (Grades 7-12), All-Level (Grades EC-12)
Description: Baylor’s Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) is a full-time, one-year master’s degree program that prepares individuals for initial teacher certification in a variety of fields and levels. The MAT program is an ideal option for recent college graduates who have a bachelor’s degree in a field other than education and who want to become a certified teacher. The program is specifically designed to prepare highly qualified individuals who have both deep content knowledge and a commitment to making a difference in the lives of children. The MAT program is unique in its focus on intensive, school-based experiences combined with rigorous graduate coursework. Throughout the program, MAT candidates are immersed in local schools and work alongside experienced mentor teachers. A full-year, supervised clinical experience provides MAT candidates with extensive opportunities to apply the knowledge and skills they are learning in their coursework.
Accredidation: The Baylor University School of Education is accredited by the Texas Education Agency (TEA) and is a member in good standing of the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education (AACTE). Baylor SOE programs are currently in the process of seeking accreditation from the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

ProgramName: Master of Taxation
EnglishScore: Baylor Graduate Admissions requires applicants whose native language is not English to submit an English proficiency test score. Minimum scores on the following tests are listed below: TOEFL (iBT) - 80, IELTS - 6.5, Duolingo - 110
Description: The MTax degree is a specialized program designed to prepare students for a career in taxation. The curriculum emphasizes a conceptual understanding of taxation as well as the development of technical and research skills. The program satisfies the 150-hour requirement to become a CPA.
Accredidation: The Baylor accounting programs are separately accredited by the AACSB, a distinction held by less than two percent of business schools worldwide.

ProgramName: Doctor of Science in Physician Assistant Studies with an emphasis in Emergency Medicine
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit a score from one of the following tests: TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language), IELTS (International English Language Testing System), PTE (Pearson Test of English), Duolingo, or completion of the ELS (English Language Services) Intensive English Program.
Requirements:
Must be a graduate of a physician assistant training program accredited by the Accreditation Review Commission on Education for the Physician Assistant (ARC-PA).
A master’s degree from a US accredited institution.
Must hold current NCCPA certification.
Must hold a current, unrestricted license to practice as a PA in a US state or territory, or be a PA in uniformed services.
Emergency Medicine Track: Must be currently working in emergency medicine.
Orthopaedic Surgery Track: Must be currently working in orthopaedic surgery.
Undesignated DScPA Track: Must have at least five years of clinical experience as a PA.
Department: Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences
Description: The Baylor University Doctor of Science in Physician Assistant Studies (DScPA) is a 12-month program with an emphasis in Emergency Medicine that is designed for the experienced, board-certified Physician Assistant who is seeking to enhance their knowledge base, skills, and professional stature. The hybrid educational format, 60-semester hour curriculum, combines distributed learning with four, one-week, on-campus immersive experiences that include work in Baylor University's state-of-the-art simulation lab. Didactic content focuses on advanced medical concepts while the clinical component provides PAs with extensive, hands-on experience in one of our many emergency medicine partner sites. The DScPA faculty are all experienced PAs who are dedicated to training the next generation of PA leaders. The DScPA curriculum has a three-fold purpose of enhancing the PA’s fund of knowledge, honing their skills, and developing a professional growth plan that prepares PAs for a lifetime of leadership and service.

ProgramName: Doctor of Science in Physician Assistant Studies with an emphasis in Orthopaedics
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit a score from an English proficiency test (TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo) unless they are exempt. Exemptions include holding a bachelor's degree from a U.S. accredited institution.
Requirements: Applicants for the Doctor of Science in Physician Assistant Studies program must hold a master's degree (e.g. MPAS, MHS, etc.) from a physician assistant program that is accredited by the Accreditation Review Commission on Education for the Physician Assistant (ARC-PA). Applicants must be certified by the National Commission on Certification of Physician Assistants (NCCPA). Applicants must maintain this certification for the duration of the program. Applicants must be licensed as a physician assistant in a US state or territory. Applicants must maintain this licensure for the duration of the program.
Department: Robbins College of Health and Human Sciences
Description:
The Baylor University Doctor of Science in Physician Assistant Studies (DScPAS) is a 65-semester hour program designed for the experienced, board-certified Physician Assistant who wishes to grow in their clinical and professional skills, with an emphasis in either Emergency Medicine or Orthopaedics. The program is offered in a hybrid format, allowing PAs to continue working while pursuing this advanced degree.

The Baylor University DScPAS program will be a leader in Physician Assistant graduate education by building on the foundation of the U.S. Military’s highly successful DScPA programs and the excellence in graduate education for which Baylor is nationally recognized. Our curriculum is designed to produce graduates who are prepared to be leaders in the PA profession through an emphasis on scholarship and service.

The program consists of didactic courses offered in an online format and a variety of supervised clinical practice experiences. Students are also required to travel to the Baylor University campus in Waco, Texas for two, one-week sessions to learn hands-on skills such as advanced procedures and point-of-care ultrasound.

Graduates of the Baylor University DScPAS program will use their advanced knowledge and skills to improve the quality and accessibility of patient care, advance the PA profession, and serve their communities.
Accredidation:
The ARC-PA has granted Accreditation-Continued status to the Baylor University Physician Assistant Program sponsored by Baylor University. Accreditation-Continued is an accreditation status granted when a currently accredited program is in compliance with the ARC-PA Standards.

Accreditation remains in effect until the program closes or withdraws from the accreditation process or until accreditation is withdrawn for failure to comply with the Standards. The approximate date for the next validation review of the program by the ARC-PA will be June 2028. The review date is contingent upon continued compliance with the Accreditation Standards and ARC-PA policy.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based fellowships and scholarships, Travel Awards

ProgramName: Doctor of Science in Physician Assistant Studies with an emphasis in General Surgery
Requirements:
The following are the prerequisites for entry into the U.S. Army-Baylor University DSc PAS Program:
1. Be a graduate of an ARC-PA accredited Physician Assistant Program.
2. Have a Master’s degree (MPAS, MHS, MMSc) from a regionally accredited university or college in the United States or Canada.
3. Have a minimum of 4 years of clinical experience as a certified PA working with a physician in one of the medical specialties.
4. Possess and maintain a current NCCPA certification.
5. Possess an unrestricted license to practice as a PA in one of the states, territories, or commonwealths of the United States.
6. Must be a member of the armed forces (Army, Navy, Air Force) or an employee of the U.S. Government.
7. Submit an application packet through the US Army Medical Department (AMEDD) Center & School to the Program Director. An application and specific instructions for completion can be obtained by contacting the program.
8. Graduate Record Examination (GRE) taken within five years. A minimum score is not specified.
Description: The Army Medical Department Center and School (AMEDDC&S) offers a Doctor of Science in Physician Assistant Studies (DScPAS) with an emphasis in General Surgery through the Graduate School at Baylor University. The program is fully accredited by the Accreditation Review Commission on Education for the Physician Assistant (ARC-PA). The 12-month program provides PAs with a robust didactic education and a concentrated clinical experience in general surgery. The goal of the program is to produce graduates with the necessary knowledge and skills to manage patients with complex surgical and critical illness. Upon successful completion of the program, the graduate will serve as a subject matter expert in general surgery and be fully capable of independent practice in a variety of settings.
Accredidation: The program is fully accredited by the Accreditation Review Commission on Education for the Physician Assistant (ARC-PA).
